title.value: Exploring social inequalities in healthcare trajectories following diagnosis of diabetes: a state sequence analysis of linked survey and administrative data
title.justification: The title is explicitly stated at the beginning of the paper.
title.quote: Exploring social inequalities in healthcare trajectories following diagnosis of diabetes: a state sequence analysis of linked survey and administrative data

extractions.description: The paper examines how social factors influence healthcare trajectories after a diabetes diagnosis using state sequence analysis on linked Canadian survey and administrative data. It identifies distinct care trajectories and evaluates their associations with sociodemographic factors.

type.justification: The paper involves the collection and analysis of data from the TorSaDe cohort and applies statistical methods to identify care trajectories.
type.quote: Methods: We used the TorSaDe (The Care Trajectories-Enriched Data) cohort, which links Canadian Community Health Survey respondents to health administrative data.

name.justification: The primary focus is on healthcare trajectories, access, and social determinants, which align with Health Services Research rather than a specific deep learning field.
name.quote: Background: Social inequalities in complications associated with diabetes mellitus persist. As a primary care sensitive condition (PCSC), this association could be related to differential access to primary care.

name.justification: The paper aims to establish a typology of care trajectories and explore social determinants using state sequence analysis.
name.quote: Methods: Care trajectories were mapped over a two-year period following a new diagnosis and analysed using state sequence and clustering methods.

name.justification: The TorSaDe cohort is the main dataset used for analysis in this paper.
name.quote: Methods: We used the TorSaDe (The Care Trajectories-Enriched Data) cohort, which links Canadian Community Health Survey respondents to health administrative data.

referenced_paper_title.value: Cohort profile: the care trajectories—enriched data (TorSaDE) cohort
referenced_paper_title.justification: The TorSaDe cohort is explicitly mentioned as used in the study, and its description suggests there is a corresponding cohort profile paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Cohort profile: the care trajectories—enriched data (TorSaDE) cohort. Int J Epidemiol. 2020;00(00):9.
